sentence.text: Patient 2 (Fig. 2B) is the 15-year-old sister of patient 1.
Like her sister, she too received an alveolar bone grafting procedure for her extensive oronasal fistula and bilateral cleft palate.
She has increased intraorbital distance and a prominent fronto-orbital contour.
She also has intermittent horizontal nystagmus but does not have significant epicanthal folding.
She has a flattened nasal root, bifidity to her nasal tip, and flatness to the nasal dorsum, which gives the exaggeration of hypertelorbitism.
Her midface has reasonable projection with a skeletal class III relationship.
She still has transverse collapse of her arch and has a quadhelix in place to expand her palate.
She has a very sharp angle, almost triangulation to her dental arch on the maxilla.
On her cleft lip repair, she has a very shortened lip.
Edges and white roll are aligned, but her columellar length is shortened.
She had an operative procedure when she was 3 months old for a closed neural tube defect.
At age 10, a magnetic resonance imaging study of her spine showed that the spinal cord was low lying and tethered.
The craniocervical junction is tight with little cerebrospinal fluid anterior or posterior to the parenchymal elements.
There are no hypointensity changes within the spinal cord.
There is slight dilatation of the central canal in the cervical and thoracic region, which varies between 2 and 3 mm and is in itself of no significance.
She has complained of intermittent back pain, which radiates down the back of her legs to the knees.
There is no history of any motor or sensory loss in the lower extremities.
Bladder function is reported to be normal.
Patient 2 has leg asymmetry: her right calf is 7 mm smaller than the left.
There is no deformation of the feet, which are the same size.
The patient can push off from the ball of one foot and do a one-legged knee bend, but it is a little difficult for her to do so on the right side.
She has more difficulty balancing on the right foot with her eyes open compared with the left.
She also has a little bit more difficulty hopping on the right foot.
She was born with bilateral iris colobomas and cloudy corneas.
She has successfully undergone corneal transplant surgeries in both eyes.
She has a small corneal scar in her left eye due to a corneal infection.
With corneal transplants, her vision has improved significantly to 4 feet/200 in the right eye and 10 feet/200 in the left.
Her vision is limited secondary to visual development and the previous clouding of the cornea.
Despite her eye trouble, she is in gifted classes in the ninth grade with accommodations for her vision needs and earns all As and Bs.
